Hi Tumblr! Today weâre gonna talk about MENTAL DISORDERS, and the actions of NON-NEURO TYPICALS and their PERCEPTION by SOCIETY AT LARGE.

Today at group therapy I shoved myself in this tight spot for a couple minutes. It was nice and tight and comfortable to me, and I KNOW I looked weird as hell but I was comfortable so idgaf.

Some of the other group members, neurotypical folk, said things to newcomers like âsheâs autisticâ and âshe doesnât realize it looks weird to you, itâs her space so all we care is that she is comfortableâ

While these statements were said with the best of intentions, they made me realize something that goes hand in hand with the gross generalization of all non-NTs; people think we all donât know we look weird as fuck to them.

Iâm here to set your NT asses straight:
Some, in fact many autistic/non-NT persons KNOW that they are âdifferentâ and that their actions might be perceived as such
-society has taught me that bobbing back in forth in my chair is strange looking to others
-society has taught me that piling shit on your lap when youâre laying/sitting down is considered abnormal
-society has told me a lot of shit, and basically I am well aware that I look goddamn strange to you and it doesnât matter to me because Iâm comfortable

Part of self care is making my self comfortable, and part of being an âallyâ means not acting like youâre so much more aware of the âabnormalâ nature of my own actions than I am

Because i am quite aware that society thinks Iâm freaky
I am just beyond caring
Thank you.

There is this whole assumption that I hear TIME AND AGAIN that when people are acting weirdly (especially Developmentally Disabled people)Â  that They must not know theyâre acting weird or otherwise they would act Normally.

ItÂ  all comes down to the idea that everyone is essentially the same inside an that Everyone Should act âNormalâ at all times.

Which is not the way the world works!Â  People are different.Â  People act differently.Â  And people have REASONS for the way they act.

And I know that society thinks I act weird.

And I am beyond caring.

And that is a Good Thing!

because it lets me get on with living my life and caring for my people.

YES YES YES THIS.

THIS IDEA THAT WEâRE WEIRD JUST BECAUSE WE DONâT NOTICE GET ON MY NERVES.
